1237834910871797760.text:
When nine African American students (known today as the "Little Rock Nine") became the first to attend the all-white Central High School, the Bates' home was the local headquarters for school integration.

Her efforts blazed the way for thousands of students across the country.

1237834909856739330.text: This #WomensHistoryWednesday, I'm honoring Ms. Daisy Bates. Ms. Bates and her husband operated the Arkansas State Press, a newspaper advocating for equal rights. After the Brown v. Board of Education ruling, Ms. Bates chronicled school desegregation.

1235329499362975746.text: Ms. Caraway served two full terms in the Senate, which included committee assignments on Agriculture and Forestry. On her final day in office, she received a standing ovation from her all-male colleagues.

1235329498637373440.text: The governor appointed Ms. Caraway, but Ms. Caraway surprised everyone when she announced she would run for a full term. "The time has passed when a woman should be placed in a position and kept there only while someone else is being groomed for the job," she told reporters.

1235329497790062599.text: Up first is Ms. Hattie Caraway, the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate in 1932. As a resident of Jonesboro, AR, Ms. Caraway initially became involved in politics when her husband, Senator Thaddeus Caraway, died in office in 1931.

1235329497039278090.text: March is #WomensHistoryMonth , a time to celebrate the incredible women in America and across the world who have shaped history. Arkansas is home to many of them, which is why I'm kicking off #WomensHistoryWednesday - to highlight Arkansan women who changed the nation.

1116009288810553346.text: This so-called attempt to "save the internet" is a gift to edge providers who want to market personal data. GOP members have introduced three bills that would protect consumers without government involvement – let’s focus our attention on those practical solutions instead.

1116009288097570816.text: This isn’t the first time we’ve debated net neutrality. When Trump first announced he was repealing regulations, liberals wouldn't stop talking about how this would radically change the internet as we knew it. But when the regulations ceased, these doomsday predictions fell flat.

1116009287493529600.text: I support the bipartisan and commonsense "bright line" rules for net neutrality – no blocking, no throttling and no paid prioritization – that protect consumers, but the Save the Internet Act reaches far beyond these commonsense protections.

1116009286684020736.text: The internet isn’t broken, so why are liberals trying to fix it? In H.R. 1644, House Democrats want to give federal entities nearly unlimited authority to regulate the internet, which is why I voted against it.

1115375228971044864.text: @SpeakerPelosi should take up a VAWA bill that focuses exclusively on protecting women from violence, instead of using her platform to push identity politics and politicize a historically bipartisan issue. /end

1115375228316790784.text: The bottom line: women deserve legislation that actually protects them and their well-being, not a partisan package that advances the far-left’s political goals. I encourage you to contact your senators and urge them to stop this bad legislation. 5/6

941076280019177472.text: @freeusa6042 @NatResources We have to do more than blame climate change for the fires. Active management is key. If we reduce the risk of catastrophic wildfires, we put less CO2 into the air and the forest can do its job - sequestering CO2. That's a huge win for the environment. (2/2)

941075894139019264.text: @freeusa6042 @NatResources I am a Yale-educated forester. I am not denying science. I am trying to use science to reduce the risk of future catastrophic fires. If we reduce the fuel load using targeted, scientifically-sound thinning, fewer acres burn and it will be easier to contain fires. (1/2)

941074426333974528.text: @freeusa6042 @NatResources Some of the largest fires in Southern California are burning in the Angeles and Los Padres National Forests.

941073881431003136.text: @SaggSyndicate @NatResources It is called silviculture, the practice of forestry. 941072814681088001.text: @freeusa6042 @NatResources We can't just blame global warming and do nothing to fix this problem of overgrown, diseased forests.
